Grazia Deledda / Nobel 26

GRAZIA DELEDDA Italian writer, best known for stories of Sardinian peasantry. Nobel Prize winner in 1926

Mary Evans Picture Library makes available wonderful images created for people to enjoy over the centuries

1875 Best Nobel Peasantry Prize Sardinian Shawl Stories Winner 1926 1936 Grazia

EDITORS COMMENTS

This evocative photograph captures the noble and introspective gaze of Grazia Deledda, the esteemed Italian writer who was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1926. Born in 1875 in Nuoro, Sardinia, Deledda is best known for her poignant and authentic portrayals of Sardinian peasantry and rural life. In this image, Deledda is seen sitting at a table, dressed in a traditional Sardinian shawl, her long, grey hair cascading down her shoulders. She is deeply engrossed in a book, her expression one of quiet concentration and dedication. Deledda's literary career spanned over five decades, from the late 19th century to the 1930s. Her works, which often explored the themes of love, loss, and the human condition, were deeply rooted in the history and culture of her native Sardinia. Her most famous novels include "Canne al vento" (Reeds in the Wind), "La sonnambula" (The Sleepwalker), and "Ecco la luna" (Behold the Moon). Deledda's Nobel Prize win in 1926 marked a significant achievement for Italian literature and for women writers in particular. She was the first Italian woman, and the fourth woman overall, to receive the Nobel Prize in Literature. Her legacy continues to inspire and captivate readers around the world, and her works remain an important part of Italian literary history.
